replies.text: The only regret I see here is not including a fund, but youve done well regardless.

Old dood here. The stock market has made a monkey out of me twice big losses. If I knew 35 years ago what I know today I would of bought an SP index and forgot about it. Individual stock picking was not my forte.

I would sell everything but the first 3 holdings. Consolidate and put into an index. You can do some individual stocks 50 and index 50 to be really safe. You want to preserve capital. You did a really good job being balanced in your positions.
Likely. Did you do the actual math?

Sorry first 4 holdings, I didnt see Amazon in there. Keep Amazon, Google, Tesla, Apple and build out from there. I do MAG7 and then 50 SPY. When I add, I look to see what Im down on and then add funds appropriately.

Its really difficult to do that math on a DCA basis. But by picking two points, yes, I calculated the different in return on investment. If I had invested my entire principle 3 years ago today I would be up 20.xx, but if we take VOOs 1 year return Aug 2, 2023, VOOs return is 17. My point is that if I had simply DCAd my capital into VOO, I wouldve also invested in the low points creating a return likely 25 without much effort.
Was gonna say lol google is not bad either. I agree though.
Yeah its something every single investor realizes over their time picking stocks its fun sometimes, addictive gambling and not worth the stress.

To me the real TLDR is The market can remain irrational longer than you can remain solvent. Basically even if you are completely right about their underlying business, the stock price doesnt have to move
TLDR Average Return 34 SP500 100 Add this to the massive pile of data showing picking stocks doesnt work and that it underperforms indexing.

OP has sacrificed years off of his retirement to provide us additional evidence that stock picking is perilous and index investing is the wiser strategy. We all owe him a debt of thanks for volunteering as a case study.
Where is Intel?

Honestly, thank you for doing this. People need to be reminded with hard evidence more often that picking stocks, even ones whose fundamentals look really good, is essentially a crapshoot. VOO and chill is really the only way any of us avoid working as a Walmart greeter into our 70s

I was banned for life for something which offended them but ironically its something they wouldnt dare ban somebody for now. Then the stock price crashed and they made me a new account lol. Id buy if they paid dividends. Theyre pretty much the payment provider of choice for all the various under the table deals that happen on Facebook and elsewhere...

Some of those did really well. Some, not very much at all. It would be a good idea to do a dive into how strong of a business the bottom half that performed poorly really are. If they have as strong of a competitive position as they appear. I dont recognize all of them, but I do have stock in some of them like TTD and the business has done very well, growing revenue and such. And becoming a leader in their DSP space in Connected TV. Microsoft and Amazon are strong businesses as well.

I expect at some point SP will have to drop the bad performers and take on new companies and this will trigger big price changes. I dont think one can time the dropping companies, but you can stay with the well performing ones without needing liquidity.

They are delivering good numbers top line, bottom line, all good, cash flow OK and the next year should be a good year for them with more coverage coming their way. Their problem is stock dilution. They issued 280M worth of stock in May and expect 50M more by the end of FY. Thats way too much for a company of their size and thats why their stock price is where it is. If they can ditch the dilution for consistent operating cash flow next year, they could double in price.
Companies get addeddropped quite frequently, this is part of the reason the SP500 index is so powerful.
The quarterly index rebalance is a feature of mostall major indices.

This could be used as a test of the OPs thesis that being included in the index props up a companys value. Once SPY or VOO reflect the rebalance, the price should shoot up for a company thats been added, or drop for a company thats been removed.

Hang in there bub. Sorry you are having to go through this at such a young age. As for the haters giving you shit because your investing plan is working, they are probably just jealous they have blown up their accounts yet again on 0dtes.

Michael Burry responded to my craigslist ad looking for someone to mow my lawn. 30 is 30, he said as he continued to mow what was clearly the wrong yard. My neighbor and I shouted at him but he was already wearing muffs. Focused dude. He attached a phone mount onto the handle of his push mower. I was able to sneak a peek and he was browsing Zillow listings in central Wyoming. He wouldnt stop cackling. That is to say, Burry has his fingers in a lot of pies. I also only do shares and am up similar percentages. Having gone through COVID, it comes crashing down far faster than it climbs. Plan for what you will do when that inevitably happens. It will happen. Good luck.

You would write puts if your shares get called away assuming you believe it can go higher. Buy for 150, write a call for 155. Shares get called away. You can write puts for 150 again as an entry point. Do you miss out on gains if it goes to 175? Yes. Should you write a put for 170 the following week? Itd be great if it goes to 200 but it could easily go back to 150 again and youll be negative. Its where the game is.

Just feed it into GPT and ask it to summarize it for you in two sentences The strategy involves combining a 7080 double calendar with a 7892 outofthemoney OTM strangle to hedge against different price movements. The double calendar profits if the price remains flat, while the OTM strangle profits if the price runs by purchasing these positions right before earnings, the trader maximizes the potential gains from the volatility crush and minimizes losses from time decay, improving the structures resilience compared to using double calendars alone.

When does the $2.9 billion of accounts receivable come back to haunt TTD. APP earns $300 million last quarter on a billion in sales and has one billion of A/R. TTD does $600 million in sales last quarter earned $85 million and has $2.9 billion in receivables. TTD is not a bank. Why is it acting like a stock exchange where is settles trades by extending credit 60 days to its participants? TTD’s answer to its high A/R balance is to simply run a high A/P balance which clearly runs the risk of alienating its vendors. TTD’s payables only get paid if those receivables are collectible. And that is a crazy business model

The Trade Desk (TTD) is well positioned in high growth digital advertising, BofA Securities said Wednesday in a report, initiating coverage of the company with a buy rating.

"Attractive top-line growth, high margins, compelling unit economics (~80% gross margins) and long runway for growth warrants a premium valuation," BofA said.

Trade Desk sustained and accelerated a competitive advantage in programmatic advertising and industry leadership despite competition from large tech companies, BofA said. "It is now a centralized marketplace for digital advertising transactions, establishing an effective 'moat,'" partly driven by artificial-intelligence initiatives, the report said.
BofA Securities Initiates Coverage on The Trade Desk With Buy Rating, $135 Price Target

that’s a new thing for them. given they haven’t really put a wrong foot forward yet, will take this as good news.

Digital advertising company.The trade desk is getting ready to more directly compete with google roku and amazon.  The company has been secretly building its own smart TV operating system, and aims to license it to device makers that don't want to run Google TV, Amazon's Fire TV OS or Roku's OS, I have been able to confirm with five sources with knowledge of the company's plans.

Representatives for The Trade Desk did not respond to multiple requests for comment.

Work on the project began during the pandemic, and has progressed largely in secret. People working on the project include former senior Roku employees, and at least some team members have been hiding the fact that they are employed by The Trade Desk on LinkedIn. Altogether, The Trade Desk is said to have dozens of people working on the project.

The Trade Desk has been pitching its smart TV OS to multiple hardware makers, with multiple sources telling me that the company is promising much more advantageous revenue sharing deals than its established competition. The company is also said to give hardware partners more leeway in customizing the user interface of the OS than companies like Roku and Amazon typically do. It is said to have signed up at least one partner thus far, and a first device running the OS could launch as early as next year.
